text: Yeah, sure. So I think the first thing to say is that since November 2022 and the FTX blow up, every institution, at least I think just everyone, takes exchange risk much more seriously now. So I think this is something where people kind of had it at the back of their mind, but maybe didn't think about it that much before FTX. And now it's a real primary concern. And this idea of a hurdle rate is something which I've heard of at many, many places trading crypto. Nick Huberman 06.00 If you have a strategy and you think I can make 20% a year on my capital deplore to the exchange for that, even if you can make that with very high sharp, what you're saying is, I need to have five years of my assets sitting at that exchange before I've made enough P&L to cover the assets that are at risk. And what do you think the chances are of that particular crypto exchange blowing up at some point in the next five years? So you really care about things like your return on capital. And even more than that, there are some... exchanges where I personally, or we as a firm, and I know many other firms just wouldn't trade on at all, almost no matter what you thought you could get from P&L from trading there, because you have things like enormous lack of transparency around the corporate structure or the ultimate beneficial owners of the exchange. Or you have concerns around very inflated volumes on the exchange, wash trading, self-dealing, the possibility of there being internal trading teams at the exchange who are going to... Nick Huberman 06.00 have advantages which are not available to external trading teams. So there are definitely some exchanges where we would not trade, which shouldn't be surprising, there are hundreds of crypto exchanges, but really maybe only 10 or so with decent volumes where an institution would feel comfortable trading. But then even for exchanges where you are comfortable trading, you still have to assign some probability that bad stuff is going to happen at some point. So that could be fraud, that could be the exchange gets hacked. It could just be some incompetence. Luke Gromen 06.00 But even for a top tier, gold-plated crypto exchange, there's a chance that something bad is going to happen at some point. One which has come up, I guess more recently the first few months of this year, is regulatory risk. What happens if the exchange gets sued by the SEC or the CFTC? And all these events could result in loss of funds. So you have to mitigate this as best you can. You can never fully remove this risk. You monitor news flow, you monitor wallet movements. You look at volumes on the exchange, you try and spot and monitor the volume. You look at the volume of shares, you try and spot the volume. thing which looks out of the ordinary and you make your threshold for getting out and just saying like i'm not happy here i'm going to remove all my assets from the exchange you make that threshold as low as you can whilst being consistent with not constantly having to hop your assets on and off the exchange and then secondly you just try to have sensible limits on what is the maximum amount of my trading capital that i'm going to put on any one exchange and i think no one sensible would ever now have 100 or even 50 or 25 percent of their capital all in one exchange certainly not if they thought they couldn't afford to lose it and then yeah the other dimension of this is the very large number of line items that you accumulate in your book especially if you're running some kind of systematic strategy or doing any kind of fast trading so you know we for example run a long short market neutral crypto book with hundreds of different underlies in the book and you know any underlier could have multiple different derivatives contracts referencing it or you can have the same token held at different exchange rates and then you can have a lot of different derivatives contracts and then you can have a lot of different derivatives contracts referencing it or you can have a lot exchanges which they can trade at different prices so in some sense even though they are to some extent fungible to some extent they're not as well you can't always move a creator asset between two different exchanges smoothly and the other thing is that crypto assets are very volatile right so you've got this big long short book you've got a lot of names in it these things have annualized volatilities in the triple digits normally so high that when we're talking about this we normally just quote daily volatilities you're talking about daily volatilities in the range of five to fifteen percent which means these things can easily move twenty five or fifty percent over the course of the day like that's not uncommon and it's definitely not unheard of for something to go to zero or to go up in price ten times within a very short span of time and this is kind of okay on the long side of your book you know if you have one percent of your book in a coin which goes to zero then you're down one percent and that sucks but it's very survivable for you but if you have one percent of your short book and an asset which goes up ten times in value over the space of two hours that's loss in your book. And you're probably trading this thing with leverage as well. And so it sounds slightly insane to trade an incredibly volatile asset with a lot of leverage, but you're counterbalancing it against your desire to not hold a lot of collateral on the exchange, because you're worried about something bad happening in the exchange. So you maybe have three or four or five times leverage in your book. And so if you have a short position, which is 1% of your book, and it goes up 10 times in value, and you're trading with five times leverage, that's half of your trading capital on the exchange gone in a single market movement. So we worry a lot about this. And we have pretty tight limits overall on how big we're ever going to allow a single position to be in our book. And we'll aggressively start getting out of stuff, if we think there's a big danger.
